title: 107_hr1967
content: The Gas Price Spike Act of 2001, also known as the Windfall Profits Tax, imposes a tax on crude oil, natural gas, and related products under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. An excise tax is imposed on the sale of crude oil, natural gas, or other taxable products in the United States, equal to a percentage of the windfall profit. Definitions include taxable product, windfall profit, and applicable percentage based on profit margins. The excise tax on the sale of taxable products is based on the profit margin, with varying percentages depending on the level of profit. The Reasonable Profits Board determines what constitutes a reasonable profit on the sale. The seller is liable for paying the taxes imposed. Chapter 55 introduces amendments related to windfall profits on crude oil and refined petroleum products. The effective date for these changes is the enactment date of the Act. Additionally, Section 3 provides a credit for purchasing fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows individuals a tax credit for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles. The maximum credit ranges from $3,000 to $6,000 based on the fuel economy of the vehicle. The tax credit for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 ranges from $3,000 to $6,000 based on the fuel economy of the vehicle. A qualified passenger vehicle must meet specific fuel economy requirements, with at least 55 miles per gallon for trucks or SUVs, and at least 65 miles per gallon for other vehicles. The vehicle must also be purchased after the enactment of this section, assembled in the US by individuals under a collective bargaining agreement, have its original use begin with the taxpayer, and be primarily used by the taxpayer. The tax credit for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 ranges from $3,000 to $6,000 based on specific fuel economy requirements. The fuel economy of the vehicle must be at least 35 miles per gallon for trucks or SUVs, and at least 45 miles per gallon for other vehicles. The basis of the property for which the credit is allowable will be reduced by the amount of the credit. No credit is allowed for property used outside the United States. The table of sections for subpart A is amended to include a new item after section 25A. "Section 25B allows for the purchase of fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles. The amendments apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. Section 4 addresses mass transit fare reductions during gas price spikes." The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to mass transit systems to reduce passenger fares equally. The definition includes bus and commuter rail systems. Appropriations are authorized based on excess revenues from the previous fiscal year. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to mass transit systems to reduce passenger fares equally, including bus and commuter rail systems. Amounts authorized for fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles shall remain available until expended. SEC. 5. REASONABLE PROFITS BOARD. The Reasonable Profits Board is established as an independent board to determine reasonable profits for the Internal Revenue Code. It consists of 3 members appointed by the President for a 3-year term, with no financial interests in relevant businesses. The Reasonable Profits Board consists of 3 members appointed by the President for a 3-year term with no financial interests in relevant businesses. Board members are paid at a rate equal to the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule and receive travel expenses. The Board appoints a Director with no financial interests in relevant businesses. The Director of the Reasonable Profits Board is paid at the rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional personnel without following standard appointment procedures and pay regulations. The Reasonable Profits Board can request personnel from federal departments, the Comptroller General can provide assistance, and the Board can hire experts or consultants through contracts. The Reasonable Profits Board has the authority to lease space and acquire personal property within available funds. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for this purpose.
